bibl.title: Letter from Isabel Riva to R.C. Derivaux, December 6, 1918

div1.p: Riva explains the difficulties of using postal cards for collecting statistical data.

div1.head: Letter from Isabel Riva to R.C. Derivaux, December 6, 1918
div1.opener:
OFFICE OF
MALARIAL INVESTIGATIONS
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
U.S. MARINE HOSPITAL
NEW ORLEANS, LA.
December 6, 1918
Dear Dr. Derivaux:
div1.p:
I am wondering if there is anything we can do to
expedite the forwarding of our postal cards from this office.
I am extremely discouraged with this part of my work, first,
by the Bureau sending the entire supply of cards here, and
second- the wrangling I have with the Express Co., to call
for the packages. I have phoned the Express Co., everyday
since the 27th ult. and as yet they have never called. They
tell me over the phone that they “will call tomorrow” but
“tomorrow” never comes. Yesterday they told me that it was
not their fault if they could not get out this far, that if
I wanted them to go any sooner than they could call I would
have to send them to the Express office myself. I had the
same trouble last month. They, then, reach the Doctors so
late it is to be supposed that little attention is paid to
the card.

If you attend the Malaria meeting please do
not fail to speak of this work. There have been delays and
confusion all along.
Delay in printing cards; confusion in sending them to this
office instead of to the Health Officers direct, the supply
of which did not reach here until the first week of Sept. On
Sept. 4, the June, July and August cards were reshipped to
the respective states. If we are to take up this work for
1919, I do hope that it can be handled more satisfactorily
or else drop it altogether as the results do not seem to jus-
tify the expense, time, etc.

I am in a quandary as to what to do about order-
ing cards for next year. Dr. Carter said that he wanted to
speak to Mr. Dublin, Statistician, in regard to the form he
(Dublin) has for collecting statistical data, at the coming
meeting, as he believes we can improve on the form we are now
sending out. He just mentioned this off hand when I told him
that it was now time to make our request for the supply for
the coming year; the many interruptions and his sudden depar-
ture prevented me from taking the matter up with him again.
Do you think I should write Dr. Carter, asking that he advise
positively if we are to defer making requisition until after
the meeting. If you remember, the Bureau has requested that
our order for cards be given at least two months in advance.
If Dr. Carter has thought over the matter and decided not to
change our form, I should like to get my requisition in at
once.
